meanings.definition: To force or coerce into doing something
meanings.sent1: The teacher dragooned the students into completing their homework on time.
meanings.sent2: The manager dragooned the employees into working overtime without proper compensation.
meanings.sent3: The coach dragooned the team into doing extra drills by promising a pizza party afterward.
meanings.sent4: The strict rules dragooned everyone into following the same routine every day.
meanings.sent5: The loud noise dragooned the sleepy cat into waking up abruptly.

meanings.definition: To compel by threats or intimidation
meanings.sent1: The bully dragooned the smaller kids into giving him their lunch money.
meanings.sent2: The dictator dragooned the citizens into supporting his oppressive regime through fear tactics.
meanings.sent3: The persistent salesman dragooned the hesitant customer into making a purchase with his aggressive pitch.
meanings.sent4: The dark clouds dragooned the picnic attendees into seeking shelter from the impending storm.
meanings.sent5: The eerie silence dragooned the curious child into exploring the mysterious attic.

meanings.definition: To press or urge into service or action
meanings.sent1: The captain dragooned the crew into preparing the ship for the long voyage ahead.
meanings.sent2: The chef dragooned the kitchen staff into creating a special menu for the grand opening.
meanings.sent3: The enthusiastic leader dragooned the team into participating in the charity event for a good cause.
meanings.sent4: The urgent message dragooned everyone into taking immediate action to prevent a disaster.
meanings.sent5: The exciting news dragooned the sleepy town into organizing a festive celebration.
